captions.text:
Hi! I’m John Green, this is Crash Course
Literature, and It’s alive!

Mr. Green? Mr. Green? That’s my favorite
part of the movie…

No. No. No. No. Me From The Past don’t you
dare. That line is not in the book. And Frankenstein

is the doctor not the monster. Also, there
is no Igor in the book or in the movie for

that matter. His name was Fritz. Let’s move
on!

So, way before you actually read Mary Shelley’s
Frankenstein, you probably heard about it...

I mean the novel is almost 200 years old now,
but we can’t seem to get away from its story
and its ideas.

Its been adapted into plays, and books, and
comics, and more than 100 movies—from your

classic Boris Karloff picture to “Blackenstein,”
“Frankenstein Meets the Space Monster,”
“The Erotic Rites of Frankenstein”...

And of course 2013’s “I, Frankenstein”
which has a resounding 4% fresh on RottenTomatoes.com

By the way I wanted to blow Crash Course’s
entire budget on licensing “The Erotic Rites
of Frankenstein” but Stan said we couldn’t!

Anyway, after all those experiences with the
story, reading the novel is kind of surprising

because it opens not with the story of Victor
Frankenstein, but with a series of letters
from an Arctic explorer.

Also, the monster, who as previously noted
is not named Frankenstein, he doesn’t have

a name that’s really important actually,
but he’s a pretty articulate guy. I mean

he reads “Plutarch’s Lives” and “Paradise
Lost.” He’s better read than most of us.

So genre wise, Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein”
is kind of a triple threat. I mean it’s

often recognized as the first work of science
fiction. It’s one of the greatest horror

novels ever. And it’s often called the greatest
capital “R” Romantic novel.

I mean like Lord Byron romantic not Danielle
Steele romantic. You know the idea that like

emotions like awe and terror and horror - the
modern emotions - can be the center of an

aesthetic experience. Also, Percy Shelley
romantic which reminds me to talk about Mary
Shelley’s biography.

Mary Shelley’s father was an anarchist author,
and her mother was Mary Walstonecraft, a famous

early feminist who died just 11 days after
Mary was born.

Her mother’s death was a huge influence
on Mary Shelley and if you’re into biographical

readings, then you can look at Frankenstein
as a story of a monstrous and disastrous birth.

Anyway, when Mary was 14, Percy Shelley, one
of the great lyric poets of the age, came

to visit her father after being thrown out
of Oxford for writing a pamphlet on atheism.

Percy Shelley was already married, but two
years later, when Mary was just 16, they eloped

to the continent along with Mary Shelley’s
stepsister Claire Clairmont… are these names
made up?

By then Mary was already pregnant with their
first child. So, it’s 16 and Pregnant, the
British Romantic Literature edition.

So a couple of years later…. oh it must
be time for the Open Letter cuz my desk just
moved.

An open letter to Percy Shelley’s heart.
Metaphorically, you were complex.

I mean after you fell in love with 16 yr old
Mary Shelley you repeatedly threatened to

commit suicide even though you were already
married to a different person named Harriet.

After leaving Harriet for this teenager, Mary,
Harriet would go on to commit suicide while
pregnant with Percy Shelley’s child.

And another woman who was in love with you,
Mary Shelley’s half-sister Fanny also committed
suicide.

But I want to talk about your literal heart
Percy Shelley, because when you drowned in

a sailing accident, your friends burned your
body and were stunned to see that your heart

did not burn. Somebody grabbed it from the
fire, it traded hands a few times, it ended

up with Mary. And it was eventually buried
with Mary and Percy’s son 67 years after
Percy died.

And some people think the reason the heart
didn’t burn is because Percy Shelley suffered

from calcification of the heart which turned
his heart almost into a bone-like structure.

In short, you were literally, hard-hearted.
Best wishes, John Green.

So a couple years later Mary Shelley, Percy
Shelley, Claire Clairmont, Lord Byron (with

whom Claire was having an affair) although
who wasn’t having an affair with Lord Byron,

and Byron’s doctor were all hanging out
in Geneva.

And despite all the lakes and chocolate, Geneva
was pretty boring, and also the weather was

unrelentingly terrible so there was nothing
to do all day except sit around reading creepy
German ghost stories.

So naturally enough, a novel-writing contest
ensued.

It was basically like the most productive
NaNoWriMo of all time. The doctor wrote a

story that would later be a huge influence
on Bram Stoker’s “Dracula,” and Mary
Shelley wrote “Frankenstein.”

She was still a teenager. It’s just not
fair! Anyway, in the introduction to the 1831

edition of the novel, Mary Shelley explained,
“How I, then a young girl, came to think

of, and to dilate upon, so very hideous an
idea.” She wanted to write a story that

would “speak to the mysterious fears of
our nature, and awaken thrilling horror.”

The idea that art could awaken that horror
and awe and connect us to the broader natural
world was really key to the romantics.

But she couldn’t figure out how to turn
ideas into like a plot until she stayed up

late one night listening to Percy Shelley
and Byron discuss new developments in electricity

and the possibility of the dead being brought
back to life. That night she went to bed and
had a terrible waking dream.

She wrote, “I saw the pale student of unhallowed
arts kneeling beside the thing he had put

together. I saw the hideous phantasm of a
man stretched out, and then, on the working

of some powerful engine, show signs of life,
and stir with an uneasy, half vital motion.
Frightful must it be.”

Uggh. it’s so creepy. Anyway, that’s Mary
Shelley’s story of the creation of Frankenstein.

Let’s talk about now what she created, the
upshot of which is: Don’t re-animate corpses.
Alright, Let’s go to the Thought Bubble

So the novel opens with with the aforementioned
boring letters that arctic explorer Walton

sends to his sister in England. Walton is
sailing toward the North Pole when he sees
a man cruising by on a dog sled.

The man is Victor Frankenstein. Once upon
a time, he was a nice Swiss boy with a couple

of younger brothers, a dead mother, a best
friend, and a cute cousin. But then he went

to university and took organic chemistry and
became obsessed with reanimating the dead

which is why you should never go to college.
Just kidding, go to college.

So eventually Victor figures out how to make
dead flesh live and he assembles this huge

creature out of dead bodies and farm animal
parts , hooks up the juice, and animates it.

Only he’s so horrified that he runs away
and conveniently develops a bad case of brain
fever.

Rejected by his creator, the monster wanders
into the wilderness where he seeks shelter
and then eventually learns to read and write.

The monster returns to Victor and he’s like
“look I’ve done so much book learning”

but that doesn’t convince Victor that the
monster is not a monster. So the monster becomes

a real monster. He kills Victor’s youngest
brother and then when Victor rejects the monster’s

request for a mate, the monster kills Victor’s
best friend and then his cousin- to whom Victor

is getting married, because, you know, that’s
what they did back then.

The creature flees to the Arctic and then
Victor pursues him which is how he ends up

on Walton’s ship where he dies. The creature,
who they’ve found, is so distraught that

he says he’s going to die too. And then
Walton has to turn the ship around and never

achieve his sublime goal, and everything’s
terrible. Because this is what happens when

you major in Organic Chemistry like my brother,
Hank, instead of something healthy and good
like film or history or literature.

Thanks Thought Bubble. So Frankenstein is
fundamentally a story about creation, about

new and terrifying ways to bring light and
life into the world. And in that sense, it’s

loosely tied to two other creation stories,
which Mary Shelley acknowledged in the text.

The first, is right there in its subtitle,
“The Modern Prometheus,” which is taken

of course from Greek mythology. Prometheus
is a Titan, he’s best known for giving fire
to Mankind - an idea that Zeus of course hated.

I don’t know why Zeus thought we couldn’t
be trusted with fire… come on, Stan, please
stop having my head blow up.

Anyway, to punish Prometheus, Zeus has him
chained to a rock and he has an eagle show

up every day to peck out Prometheus’s liver,
which then grows back every night, until Hercules
stages the ultimate prison break.

Read one way, this myth is a cautionary tale.
If you overreach yourself, if you share secret

knowledge, you’re going to get you liver
pecked out everyday, but that’s not how

the Romantics read it. To them Prometheus
was a hero. They saw Prometheus as a figure

who never gives up even when faced with incredible
suffering.

But “Frankenstein” has a more ambivalent
relationship to the myth. I mean you can definitely

read the novel as a story about what happens
when humans overstep. After all, that’s

what Mary Shelley says when she tells the
story of her dream, that Frankenstein’s
creation would be horrifying because quote

“supremely frightful would be the effect
of any human endeavour to mock the stupendous
mechanism of the Creator of the world.”

And Victor Frankenstein is certainly punished
for his actions, right, I mean he see’s

the murder of his friends and family and then
he dies a tragic icy death at the ripe old
age of 25.

Which for the record high school students,
is not old.

But you can also read “Frankenstein” another
way. As a celebration of ambition and super-human

effort. I mean, why is that whole arctic explorer
frame a thing?

Frankenstein only begins to tell Walton his
story when Walton suggests that he is willing

to risk his own life and that of his crew
for knowledge.

So it seems like Victor’s trying to share
his own experience as a cautionary tale.

But then, at the end, when crew demands that
Walton turn back SO THAT EVERYONE DOESN’T

DIE, Victor is furious. “Oh! be men, or
be more than men,” he says. “Return as

heroes who have fought and conquered, and
who know not what it is to turn their backs
on the foe.”

But Walton defers to the crew, writing his
sister, “Thus are my hopes blasted by cowardice
and indecision; I come back ignorant and disappointed.”

So I don’t think the novel is arguing that
like the heroic human life is one that lives
in a quiet bubble of ignorance.

That kind of ambivalence—We shouldn’t
overreach! Wait, except at sometimes maybe

we should!—is typical of the novel and it’s
also typical of Mary Shelley herself. She

once wrote in her journal, “I am not a person
of opinions because I feel the counterarguments
too strongly.”

The other creation myth with which “Frankenstein”
is intertwined is of course the biblical one

as recounted by John Milton in the very good,
very long “Paradise Lost,” which we aren’t

reading in Crash Course Literature because
I didn’t wanna.

One thing to pay attention to in books is
what books the characters are reading and

it’s no coincidence that the monster conveniently
reads “Paradise Lost”.

Plus the novel’s epigraph comes from Milton
in a scene in which Adam says to God:

Did I request thee, Maker, from my clay
To mould me Man, did I solicit thee
From darkness to promote me?

It’s essentially the same thing as when
you say to your parents “I didn’t ask

to be born!” but of course that doesn’t
make as good of an epigraph.

So in this interpretation Victor is playing
God and the creature is the sinning Adam.

But it’s hardly so simple I mean Victor
refers to the creature as a devil and the
creature seems to support this at times.

Plus, In the middle of the book they have
this intense argument about moral philosophy—you

know as you do with monsters, Godzilla was
into Immanuel Kant, King Kong, of course,

huge fan of Thomas Hobbes - anyway, the monster
says, “I am thy creature; I ought to be

thy Adam; but I am rather the fallen angel,
whom thou drivest from joy for no misdeed.

Everywhere I see bliss, from which I alone
am irrevocably excluded.”

It’s hard out there for a monster and it’s
important to remember that God did not expel
Satan for no misdeed.

But part of what makes this so rich is that
both “Frankenstein” and “Paradise Lost”

defy easy reading. I mean, “Frankenstein”
allies the creature with Satan but that doesn’t

mean the creature is all bad. There are readings
of Milton’s poem that perceive God as sort

of a stick in the mud and Satan as the really
interesting character who struggles undaunted
despite his exile from heaven.

Anyway, that was the view the Romantics took
and part of why the poet Robert Southey referred

to Byron and Percy Shelley and their circle
as belonging to the Satanic school of Romanticism.

But anyway, all these allusion to Milton bring
up some pretty tough questions: I mean Does

Victor see himself as God? And if so is he
a good God? Does the monster deserve his exile?

Is he inherently sinful or is sin something
that God allows to enter, as in Milton’s

poem? Just as we wonder whether Victor and
Walton should be praised or damned for their

pursuit of knowledge we have to wonder that
about the monster as well.

Whether we’re talking about mad scientists
or the monsters they create or arctic explorers,

seeking knowledge is a way of becoming human.
Both in the best and worst senses of the word.

And to me the great question of the novel
is: Who’s more human - Victor of the monster
he has created?

Next week we’ll continue our discussion
of “Frankenstein” by examining those questions

through different lenses. Until then thanks
for watching.

Crash Course is made by all of these nice
people and it exists because of your support
at Subbable.com.

Subbable is a voluntary subscription service
that allows people who love CrashCourse to
keep it free for everyone forever.

There’s also lots of great perks so please
check it out. Thank you again for watching

and as we say in my hometown, “Don’t forget
to be awesome”.

title: Don't Reanimate Corpses! Frankenstein Part 1: Crash Course Literature 205

comments.text:
"God did not expel Satan for no misdeed."  Well, from a certain 
perspective, he did.  What did Satan do?  He told the truth.  That eating 
the forbidden fruit would give them free will and the knowledge to use it. 
 They would no longer simply be god's automatons, but that they would be 
able to choose for themselves what is good and what is evil.﻿

comments.author: LongDistanceLoving

comments.text:
Now that was interesting.  There are more acts of life-creation than God's 
and Frankenstein's, there is the natural process of procreation.  While it 
is interesting that Mary's mother died shortly after Mary's birth, it is 
also interesting that she herself was pregnant when she started writing 
Frankenstein.

Perhaps she saw herself as a monster who had killed her mother.  Or perhaps 
some guilt about her, and Percy's, original marriages caused her to fear 
that the relationship would produce a monster.  Would the child be 
tainted?  Would she see the child as tainted even though the child was not?

How much responsibility can we take for our children?  Can we bring them 
into the world for our reasons and not respect that on arrival they are a 
new person, with their own needs (the monster's desire for a mate) which 
should be respected?  If they are monsters, is it our fault or theirs?

If we fear monstrousness which is not there, because of guilt that we 
violated divine law by bringing them into being (Frankenstein usurping God, 
or Mary and Percy violating their original marriages) what effect could 
that have on the child?﻿

comments.text:
hi, i'm a mythologist. you asked a great question. is Victor F more human 
than the monster? my answer is a resounding NO. Victor cuts up body parts. 
his creation reads Milton. the physician/scientist is hellbent on creating 
the unnatural, while the monster/child just wants a nice kiss. but, 
rejected, goes on a rampage. who wouldn't? i am reminded of the moment when 
Gene Hackman, in the movie, "Young Frankenstein", having fed the monster, 
and he runs away (monster runs away, that is), says "Hey! I made espresso!" 
once rejected, you can't really go back.﻿

comments.text:
Several points to address in John's summary in the Thought Bubble:

Elizabeth was only referred in the book as Victor's "cousin", but instead 
she was his adopted sister. She is also blond with blue eyes.
Victor became obsessed with the dead due to his readings of Cornelius 
Agrippa.

When the monster was in the wild, he lived near a cottage with a family of 
three (which eventually grew to four) and learned from them the values of 
family and happiness. He eventually attempt to make direct contact with the 
family, only to have the family run away in terror. 

When the monster confronted Frankenstein, it was in a cave and by 
blackmail. 

His "cousin" was already married to Victor, and was murdered by the monster 
on her wedding night. 

Please support this comment so it might clear up some things from the 
Thought Bubble.﻿
comments.author: Joy Zheng

To me Frankenstein illustrates the churlish fear of humans in their 
scientific endeavor.
Frankenstein had achieved the technique to build a new organism, but he 
couldn't accept it or adjust his world view to it.
Although it's, no doubt, a fable of horror - to me it is also a call to 
open mindedness.﻿

comments.author: Janet Jones

comments.text:
Am I the only one who doesn't think Frankenstein isn't scary? He's just a 
creature who is like any other human: really, he is a human. He follows 
Maslow's pyramid. He WANTS his creator (Vickytor) to be happy and proud of 
him, and earns it pretty well, he reads up and is smart, and only turns to 
murder when his kind of reasonable requests are turned down just because he 
is different, because his creator is too ashamed to see beyond his original 
prejudices of the so-called "monster". He is not really a monster: he is as 
human as us, more than Victor.﻿
comments.author: bucca2

comments.text:
Good point. That does make the book truly terrifying instead of merely

comments.author: Ian Segard

comments.text:
+bucca2 I think that the "scary" part of this book at the time was actually 
the horror of emotions and the horror that something that is not human 
might actually be better than humans and the terrifying idea that humanity 
is really flawed. I don't think Mary Shelly intended for the plot to be 
scary.

comments.author: Ian Segard

comments.text:
+Ian Segard I thought Victor was an asshole, seriously. I read Frankenstein 
for my AP Literature class, and my god, I just wanted to hug the creature 
like every five seconds. Victor has a horrible track record of making 
mistakes, realizing he's made a mistake, and then doing NOTHING to fix 
anything and instead sinking into crippling depression, forcing his friends 
and family to give up their time and effort to wait on him hand and foot 
while the poor creature, who did nothing wrong, suffers from the lack of 
love and care Victor shows him. I have a lot of feelings about the creature 
Dx

comments.author: Savanna Stewart

comments.text:
The way the creature was made is really unclear in the book but it doesn't 
seem to be by stitching pieces of corpses together. It is said that 
Frankenstein uses bones, after learning how to create a body from unknown 
material, so my best guess is that he assembles the organs and everything 
else to make sure his creation is "perfect". And on top of that he put 
skin, or some sort of envelope, but in a way that should have made the 
creature beautiful. The creature is not monstrous because of obvious 
difformities, only because he was man-made and thus unnatural. I'm annoyed 
that the filmic adaptations always use variations of the same design. We 
could imagine something more like a homonculus, or even that some parts 
could be mechanical or at least, not corpse bits. Anyway...﻿

comments.author: Defiant Moon

comments.text:
I interpreted the tale as a statement about the tragedy that results from a 
failure to be a good parent. Victor rejected his role as a parent and the 
Creature reacted to that rejection. Deprived of a constructive influence 
and knowing nothing but rejection and fear, what else was he to become? 
Denied the ability to become a man, the child became the only thing he was 
allowed to be: a monster. Victor's moral failing was not in overreaching, 
it was in refusing the responsibilities of being a father. ﻿

comments.author: Tamaki742

comments.text:
I haven't read all the comments, there are lots, so I apologize if someone 
else has said this same thing. I read for a while and didnt see anything 
like this so I'm posting what I feel was missing in the video. 
Though the themes of extenal appearance and rejection were discussed there 
was no mention of how that echoed Shelley's life in regards to education. 
She was never formally educated but, according to Wikipedia and my gothic 
lit class, she made extensive use of her father's library and read all the 
time. She was intellegent but would never have the respect of her male 
peers simply because she was a woman. The idea that the monster is 
consistantly judged based on his appearance and not his mind or heart is a 
reflection of her own experiences in life. Also, the few oportunities she 
might have had for deep female or maternal relationships ended before they 
began with the death of her mother right after she was born but also with 
the death of her first stillborn daughter. Her step mother was also not 
kind to her and chose to educate her step sister and not her. Isolation, 
loneliness and rejection as a result of how you were born is a very strong 
theme in the book, the monster for not asking to be a monster (or to be 
born at all) and in her life as an intellegent woman in a world that 
doesn't value her. She did not ask to be a woman but was still lonely and 
isolated as a result of it. Perhaps the monster's request for a bride was 
Shelley wishing she'd had an intellectual female equal, a mother or 
daughter, to share in her isolation. I really wish the video had touched on 
how the book was a reflection of the isolation she felt from her male peers 
who were unlikey to have valued her intelect simply because she was a 
woman, something she did not chose.

Anna Matthes﻿
comments.author: Terry Matthes

comments.text:
I always thought, in a way, that Frankenstein is a story of science without 
responsibility. Victor creates the monster then refuses to take 
responsibility for his creation, and he suffers greatly for it. The monster 
is the only true innocent, in the beginning, but he is entirely a product 
of Victor's denial of his creator responsibilities. Makes you think how 
things would have been different if Victor had accepted his creation as a 
new being and not shunned it in horror as a monster.﻿
comments.author: Anders4189

comments.text:
My interpretation of the book left a bad taste in my mouth. To me, Victor 
was painted as a good man corrupted by his ambitions, who overstepped the 
boundaries of humanity, and thought himself a god. And the monster was a 
lost and misguided child. Whenever who would take a step in the right 
direction, or did a good deed, he would be punished for it, simply because 
of his status as an abomination. That would have all worked, if it wasn't 
for the narrative, the voice of the book itself, seemingly implying the 
both Victor and the monster deserved to die.
To me, the book was about how we not only will be judged by our actions, 
but sometimes also for the way we were born. I felt that it promoted an 
idea that a person can be born into the world tainted. I ultimately didn't 
like the novel because of this. The very notion that someone deserves to be 
punished, or even killed, because of they way they were born is one that 
I'm repulsed by. ﻿

comments.author: NaiOni

comments.text:
I would argue that Victor was not a good man in any way.  He's largely 
self-serving, even his ambitions were founded upon seeking fame.  When he 
creates the monster, he becomes the architect of his own destruction.  By 
the end of the book Victor and the creature are essentially mirrors of each 
other.  They're alone in the world, with the destruction of the other being 
their only motivation left to live.  Hell, the monster immolates himself 
after Victor dies, citing that 'no more lives are necessary to attain [his] 
goals', in so many words.
comments.author: John Huddleston

comments.text:
Really? Personally I interpreted the books attitude towards the monster not 
as "It doesn't deserve to live in this world" but as "It cannot exist 
peacefully in this world". Throughout the book the monster is portrayed as 
intelligent, good natured (at least in the beginning) and even a little 
charming if you consider his encounter with the old man, however in spite 
of these traits he can only inspire an instantaneous fear and loathing in 
the people who see his body. Because humans are horrible the monster would 
never be safe and because humans are horrible the monster could only come 
to hate us for our rejection. He is dangerous not only because he's strong 
but because we would actively seek to destroy him and force him to defend 
himself, and he can't live in this world because his knowledge that we 
exist but also that he could never safely interact with us would make the 
experience unbearable. I've always read him as a sympathetic character.
Victor is pretty much the only character that says that the monster doesn't 
deserve to live but what he means is that he should never have created it, 
that playing God was a mistake. He's also mostly influenced by his own 
guilt and shame at his own actions, not by anything actually about the 
creature until it turns violent, which is pretty much (if not entirely) 
because of the way Victor treated it. Actually if you really think about it 
most of what Victor says about the monster could be referring to himself. 
What I read from the story is that mankind is monstrous, especially when 
faced with what it perceives to be a monster. It seemed like the characters 
wanted death as an escape from terrible hardship, not because they felt 
they deserved it... well the monster did but that's because of all the 
murdering and whatnot, he feels he deserves the death penalty which is the 
punishment for murder anyway.

It's entirely open to your interpretation as well though, I can see where 
you saw that I just find it fascinating that we both walked away with such 
different messages.
comments.author: Eon2641

comments.text:
I'm fairly certain Shelley wasn't arguing that the Monster deserved to be 
treated in the way it was. You shouldn't dislike the book because of that, 
just the actions and attitude of Victor. Would you dislike a book that 
chronicled the life/hardship of someone who suffered homophobia, or racism 
because that's what it portrays?
